caption: What an incredible cemetery! My wife and I were walking by and decided to stop and look around and it literally felt like we were transported to another realm! The noises and sounds of the city fade into nothingness as you enter through the gates and the world of the dead. The tombs were incredibly intricate and beautiful and the narrow pathways lined with ancient trees added to the other worldly ambiance üòäüëçüá´üá∑

04/2018 Quiet, beautiful place near place Trocadero and Eiffel Tower Lookover. Old historical tombs, interesting history, great works of art. Some famous people's final  resting place. Great atmosphere away from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Walked in totally by chance since I was walking twords the Eiffel Tower. I was amazed with the sculptures and the many stained glass windows in the monuments.
Small and with a lovely view of the Eiffel Tower. Has free restrooms. Wasn‚Äôt able to find Debussy but spent some time with Manet. Great place for a quiet time

It's located in complex Trocad√©ro but it's calm and you can feel a different atmosphere.  There are famous persons' tombs(Debussy, Manet..etc)but it's not easy to find them. At the entrance, there is a map to find easily.

This was a super cool place to walk around and see the old names that were popular. Coming from the U.S. it‚Äôs very interesting to see how far the dates go back to. It‚Äôs free to just walk in. Unfortunately, we got there 20 minutes until close so we didn‚Äôt get to explore quite enough, but I‚Äôd definitely recommend it!

My favorite place visited in Paris. Originally went to simply find the grave of Claude Debussy, my favorite composer; but I found so much more! Americans like me, especially those over 40, will surely recognize many of France's most famous names here, especially those from the fields of music, art, fashion, politics and perfumery. Even some famed non-French greats may be found here, like the Shah of Iran's daughter who committed suicide when she was 31. Her grave is always adorned by live flowers. This is an especially good place to go if the day is hot and the tourists too thick. It is cool, shady, solitary and quiet here -- a feast for the eyes and soul. Many beautiful mausoleums containing lovely stained glass. The graves themselves are often works of art. Highly recommended.

A wonderful old cemetery where some of France's greats are buried: Edouard Manet and Berthe Morisot, both famed for their impressionist paintings. It's a fun walk around the numerous imposing headstones.

Interesting cemetery away from all the hustle and bustle of Trocad√©ro. Come here for all bit of quiet and see the large tombstones and continually be rewarded with the Eiffel Tower poking up among the graves!
Take the time to explore this gem! Look for the famous crypts and take in the details of the crypts through the windows. It was very quite while we were there and allowed for a leisurely exploration.
This is a beautiful small cemetery. If you can't make it to the bigger one on the other side of the city I highly recommend coming to visit this one.
So many beautiful cemeteries in Paris, this one in particular has a special meaning. Beautiful ü•∞‚ù§Ô∏è ‚Ä¶
This is where my little brother was burried after he fell off the Eiffel Tower. The food was great, would kill a sibling again.
Cemetery and Tour Eiffel, what a surprise

A long avenue of chestnut trees surrounds the Passy cemetery, a few steps from the Trocadero. While everyone admires the Eiffel Tower, about to turn on its sparkling lights, my steps cross the door of one of probably the most famous cemeteries in Paris. Located in the elegant Muette district, the cemetery is home to great names from the fin de si√®cle aristocracy and beyond, artists, politicians, everyone now enjoys the view of the Eiffel Tower. It's not that bad I said to myself and just before the caretaker closed the old art deco door I left while a buzz rose from the tombs.

This cemetery is particularly interesting to visit, the majority of people who rest in this cemetery have a link with History. The cemetery being small, you can walk around without any problem. No other visitors on the day of my visit.

Opened in 1820, it is the smallest of the 4 Parisian cemeteries. As the sign indicates, its location in the west makes it the favorite cemetery of the bourgeois class, the political, military, financial and industrial worlds. There are also well-known personalities from the artistic world. 2 stars only, because nothing is indicated: not a single street name or division. And sometimes, the graves do not correspond to the number noted. Some graves: Marcel Dassault; Louis-Ernest Barrias; Princess of Iran Leila Pahlavi; the Cognacq-Jays; Thierry Roland, Haroun Tazieff, etc.....

A plan of the famous tombs (Fernandel, Dassa, Drucker, Manet, Debussy, Gerard de Villier 'sas,...) is located just at the entrance, no plans to take away or indication of division, but the place is small so easy to find your way. well maintained and fairly flat. You have a view of the Eiffel Tower for almost eternity.
Location far from the crowds, very well maintained cemetery. Lots of famous people. To see a stone's throw from the Trocad√©ro.
Very beautiful cemeteryüëç...not so sought after among the 4 Parisian cemeteries, because the smallest but really worth the visit! ‚Ä¶

Clear cemetery near the Trocadero. We discovered the tomb of the actor Fernandel (Don Camillo) here. You can also find here: The aircraft manufacturer Marcel Dassault, the composer Claude Debussy, the painter √âduard Manet, the car manufacturer Marcel Renault, General Charles Huntzinger, who led the ceasefire disorders with Germany in 1940. Farah Diba's mother and Princess Leila Pahlavi are also buried in this small cemetery for Parisian cemeteries. If you take a closer look at the Parisian cemeteries, you can't ignore the relevant literature. I have several books that deal with the history and stories of the individual cemeteries. It makes sense that you can often borrow an overview plan with an alphabetical order of the prominent gravesites from the individual cemetery administrations.

I'm not particularly a fan of cemeteries. But I saw a piece of greenery from below and I thought there was a park. I saw beautiful old monuments, the tombs of some famous people. And apparently there are others.
Cemetery next to the Trocad√©ro and with views of the Tour Eiffel. It houses tombs of illustrious people. Free access.

Very beautiful cemetery where it is pleasant to stroll between the tombs of the numerous and diverse personalities buried there. From Fernandel to Loulou Gast√©, from Debussy to Jean-Pierre Giraudoux, from Hubert de Givenchy to Pierre-Fran√ßois Guerlain...The person at reception is very friendly. A pleasant memory of this visit to the Passy cemetery.
small cemetery a stone's throw from the Trocadero stop: among the famous people I only found the actor Fernandel and the last daughter of the Pahlavi Shah of Persia Leila
Small cemetery with beautiful sculptures. The last emperor of Vietnam, Dr. Blanche among others.

I came to see and say hello to Professor Debussy. To be honest, it was difficult to find the cemetery, but there were only two rotten tangerines lying in the bluestone graveyard quietly located in the corner, so I came to clean them up. If you are visiting, please note that Debussy is buried in the most unlikely place in the corner.
Located next to the Trocadero. Here you don't feel any of the hustle and bustle next door.
Go take a look at the Tomb of Togrul Narimanbekov, you will discover a magnificent glass reproduction of a painting by the artist! (Congratulations to the stained glass artist)
Visit the grave of the last Emperor Bao Dai of Vietnam's Feudal regime

Very pretty cemetery, unfortunately, we didn't have much time to explore it further but we will come back, the main thing for me was to see the tomb of Claude Debussy of whom I am a fan. I wanted to highlight the excellent welcome from the lady at the entrance to the cemetery as well as the gentleman who works on maintenance, kindness is a precious thing these days so congratulations to them!......

Small cemetery where many personalities such as Debussy or Fernandel are buried as well as many aviators, a few cats wander between the graves. The entrance is located on the Jose Marti square side, more or less opposite the Maritime Museum.

Beautiful cemetery, we are happy to have seen the grave of Fernandel, of Leyla Pahlavi among others but on the other hand the person at the reception this Saturday July 10 Around 2:00 p.m. not very friendly not warm. We had the impression of bothering him to inform us. This person is not his place. Count Fran√ßois Desquesne

Very nice cemetery, alas, we do not have much time to find out more forward but we will return the principal for me was to see the tomb of Claude Debussy that I'm a fan. I wanted to highlight the excellent reception of the lady at the entrance of the cemetery and the gentleman who works in maintenance, kindness is valuable thing these days, so well done to them! ......  Very pretty cemetery, unfortunately, we didn't have much time to explore it further but we will come back, the main thing for me was to see the tomb of Claude Debussy of whom I am a fan. I wanted to highlight the excellent welcome from the lady at the entrance to the cemetery as well as the gentleman who works on maintenance, kindness is a precious thing these days so congratulations to them!......

Very quiet and very interesting Parisian cemetery. Among the famous tombs, we can note Count Emmanuel de las Cases, author of the Sainte-H√©l√®ne memorial, as well as G√©rard de Villiers, the unforgettable author of the SAS series who lived not far away on Avenue Foch.
Small little-known cemetery, very nice to visit, you will find there the tomb of Marcel Dassault and other "celebrities", very calm, relaxing, view of the Eiffel Tower.

Extravagance right up to the coffin! A place that will please taphophiles ‚ö∞‚ò†! Behind Paul Landowski's war memorial, Place du Trocad√©ro, is the Passy cemetery which has housed the graves of the cream of the Parisian bourgeoisie since the 19th century. Like the opulent lives of their occupants, some tombs are... extravagant. If you don't particularly like looking at the tombs, you can always enjoy the exceptional view of the Palais de Chaillot, the Seine and the Eiffel Tower!

To visit, there are so many tombs of famous people but sometimes you really have to have the time to look for them. ATTENTION, it is often indicated that the actress Annabella (1907-1996) is there, this is an error, rather a confusion with the town of Passy in Haute-Savoie (74). Indeed, Annabella rests in the Passy cemetery, in Haute-Savoie (74)!
